IL-6 and IFN- were significantly induced from 1 day after H5N1 HPAIV infection. macrophage-stimulating factors, including MCP-1, MIP-1, and G-CSF, increased 6 to 9 days after infection. in mice infected with H1N1 pdm 2009 virus, the viral titers in lung tissue gradually decreased over time. however, many kinds of cells (eg, vascular endothelial cells, pneumocytes, some macrophages, and epithelial cells) were infected with H5N1 HPAIV. avian influenza24 viruses are known to induce DAD in humans. virus NP protein was detected at low levels in mice infected with pdm 2009 virus. the envelope contains two large surface-exposed glycoproteins: HA and neuraminidase. the latter is responsible for attachment and penetration of virus into host cells. paired serial sections of lung tissue revealed the presence of NP and H5N1-HA in overlapping regions of the lung. we speculate that histochemical staining for H5N1-HA will provide greater sensitivity than for NP. cytopathic destruction is expected to lead to alveolar damage. a massive infiltration of macrophages has been observed in the lungs of H5N1-infected humans and mice. influenza infection of macrophages stimulates production and release of proinflammatory cytokines. the direct viral injury to type II pneumocytes may impair these cells’ functions, including re-epithelialization after alveolar damage. excessive accumulation of macrophages in the lungs could contribute to tissue damage by causing vascular injury and destruction of the parenchymal cells.
